author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: 430 Inches of Snow and an $89 Lift Ticket: Wolf Creek’s Laid-Back Appeal
description: The family-owned mountain is a throwback to an earlier era of skiing, with no on-mountain lodging, few crowds and modest amenities.
content: It was a gorgeous, cloudless February day and the skiing at Wolf Creek Ski Area, in southwestern Colorado, was superb. The snow was the soft, squeaky kind as I darted in the glades and lapped run after run on sparsely populated groomers. It all felt great. But somehow my lingering memory of that day is of another moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Katherine Maher Named C.E.O. of NPR
description: Ms. Maher was previously chief executive of the Wikimedia Foundation, a nonprofit that supports the online encyclopedia Wikipedia.
content: NPR announced on Wednesday that Katherine Maher would be its next chief executive, picking a leader with an extensive track record in the nonprofit world but without one in the realm of public radio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How Sofía Vergara Created Her Tony Soprano Role
description: This star of “Modern Family” said that nuance was crucial to her portrayal of the Miami drug lord Griselda Blanco in the new Netflix miniseries “Griselda.”
content: When Sofía Vergara invited the “Narcos” showrunner Eric Newman to her home in Los Angeles in 2015 to pitch a TV show about the Colombian drug lord Griselda Blanco, she’d done her research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Dozens Feared Dead in Collapse of Informal Gold Mine in Mali
description: The episode in the country’s southwest highlights the risks faced by miners working in environments with little to no safety measures.
content: Scores of people have died in the West African nation of Mali after an informal gold mine collapsed last week, the country’s Ministry of Mines said on Wednesday, highlighting the risks that countless artisanal miners face in one of Africa’s largest gold-producing countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon
title: Man Arrested on 77 Counts of Murder in Johannesburg Building Fire
description: The police said a 29-year-old had confessed to starting the August fire that tore through a derelict, overcrowded building occupied by poor people.
content: The South African police have arrested a man who confessed to having caused a fire that killed 77 people in a derelict building in downtown Johannesburg last year after a drug dispute led him to strangle a man and set the body alight, a police spokeswoman and a victims’ advocate said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A Lincoln Trove Lands at the Library (Pie Safe Included)
description: The New York Public Library is acquiring the collection of Jonathan Mann, an Abraham Lincoln expert who died last summer after a random attack on the Manhattan Bridge.
content: The New York Public Library’s grand research library at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street is home to Virginia Woolf’s walking stick, Charles Dickens’s desk chair and the original Winnie-the-Pooh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Arizona G.O.P. Chairman Resigns After Tape Suggests Attempt to Bribe Kari Lake
description: The chairman, Jeff DeWit, denied the conversation amounted to bribery, and said Ms. Lake, a Senate candidate, had threatened to release another damaging recording if he did not step down.
content: The chairman of Arizona’s Republican Party resigned abruptly on Wednesday, a day after the publication of a 10-minute recording of a conversation between himself and Kari Lake, a former nominee for governor, in which he appeared to offer a bribe to persuade Ms. Lake to drop her 2024 Senate campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa and Mira Rojanasakul
title: Where Groundwater Levels Are Falling, and Rising, Worldwide
description: Data from more than 1,000 aquifers reveal widespread decline, but improvement in some places shows the trend can be reversed.
content: An investigation into nearly 1,700 aquifers across more than 40 countries found that groundwater levels in almost half have fallen since 2000. Only about 7 percent of the aquifers surveyed had groundwater levels that rose over that same time period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen L. Carter
title: College Is All About Curiosity. And That Requires Free Speech.
description: True learning can only happen on campuses where academic freedom is paramount — within and outside the classroom.
content: I have served happily as a professor at Yale for most of my adult life, but in my four-plus decades at the mast, I have never seen campuses roiled as they’re roiling today. On the one hand are gleeful activists on the right, taking victory laps over the tragic tumble from grace of Harvard’s president, Claudine Gay. On the other is a campus left that has spent years crafting byzantine and vague rules on hate speech that it suddenly finds turned back on its allies. For those of us who love the academy, these are unhappy times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Popular Thai Opposition Politician Wins Election Law Case
description: But the legal troubles for Pita Limjaroenrat, who was blocked by the military junta from becoming prime minister, are far from over.
content: Pita Limjaroenrat, the popular politician who was blocked from becoming Thailand’s prime minister, cleared a legal hurdle on Wednesday after the country’s Constitutional Court found that he was not guilty of violating election law, allowing him to be reinstated as a lawmaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Court Finds Trudeau Overreached by Using Emergency Law to End Blockade
description: The government said it will appeal the decision that came two years after the start of a trucker protest that paralyzed the downtown of Canada’s capital.
content: A Canadian court found that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s use of the country’s Emergencies Act to end a truck convoy protest that had paralyzed the capital, Ottawa, two years ago was an unjustified infringement of civil rights, including the protection against unreasonable search and seizure, and, in some instances, the freedom of expression as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Benjamin Mullin
title: The Sports Illustrated Cover, a Faded Canvas That Once Defined Sports
description: It used to be the most coveted real estate in sports journalism. But its power to set the agenda disappeared along with its elite photographers.
content: Maybe it was the wordless image of the United States Olympic hockey team celebrating the “Miracle on Ice.” Perhaps it was the perfect frame of Dwight Clark making “The Catch” to send the San Francisco 49ers to the 1982 Super Bowl. Or it could have been the declaration that a 17-year-old LeBron James was “The Chosen One,” 20 months before he played in his first N.B.A. game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Tell Us What Happened to Your House in the Divorce
description: The New York Times is looking to talk to people about how they divided their property assets during a divorce.
content: Do you have a story to tell about what happened to your house during a divorce? The New York Times wants to hear how couples divided the value of their homes, likely their largest asset, and what the experience was like for them: Did you sell it and split the proceeds? Did you continue to live in it together, but in separate spaces? Did you alternate who lived in the house to accommodate custody arrangements? We are particularly interested in speaking with people who learned or discovered something new during the process, or had a memorable experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Hillary Clinton on ‘Barbie’ Snubs: You’re ‘More Than Kenough’
description: The former presidential candidate joined the chorus of disappointment in the omission of Greta Gerwig and Margot Robbie from the best director and best actress Oscar categories.
content: It was hard for fans of last year’s blockbuster film “Barbie” to ignore the twist of fate on Tuesday when Greta Gerwig, the movie’s director, and Margot Robbie, its titular star, were shut out of the best director and best actress Oscar categories. It could have quite literally been a plot point in the movie, which serves as a lesson on the patriarchal structures that shape our institutions and our ways of thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Bounty Hunter Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison for Kidnapping Woman
description: Prosecutors said Wayne D. Lozier Jr., 45, of Louisiana, traveled to Missouri to apprehend a woman for a bail bond company that had hired him. But he wasn’t properly licensed in Missouri, the authorities said.
content: A bounty hunter convicted of kidnapping a woman from her home in Missouri and trying to take her to Louisiana was sentenced on Wednesday to 10 years in prison, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Good News for Rich Uncles and Orphaned Heiresses.
description: A mystery-novel motive for murder may be too far in the past.
content: You may remember that I’ve been blitzing my way through murder mysteries this winter. As it turns out, one Agatha Christie mystery is fun, two are interesting, but once you get past three or four, they start to raise real questions about the economic incentives of the early 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Country Singer Chris Young Is Arrested at a Nashville Bar
description: The musician was released on bond for charges of disorderly conduct, assaulting an officer and resisting arrest.
content: Chris Young, the country music singer, was arrested on charges of disorderly conduct, assaulting an officer and resisting arrest after an altercation at a bar in Nashville on Monday night, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 24, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 24, 2024.
content: Because of an editing error, a Critic’s Notebook article on Tuesday about two Cleveland Orchestra concerts at Carnegie Hall misspelled the clarinetist’s surname in one instance. He is Afendi Yusuf, not Yusef.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: wistfully
description: This word has appeared in 44 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word wistfully has appeared in 44 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 16 in the Magazine article “Sean Paul Is Still Busy” by Iva Dixit:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pitchfork, the Early Years
description: With the music website’s future uncertain, Ryan Schreiber and Chris Kaskie look back at its start.
content: Last week, Condé Nast announced that Pitchfork, the taste-making music news and criticism website it had acquired in 2015 — which had entranced and sometimes infuriated fans for more than two decades — would be brought under the editorial umbrella of GQ. Many staffers were laid off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘Aristocrats,’ an Irish Dynasty Confronts Reality
description: A once-powerful clan gathers for a family wedding and muddles through the facts and fiction of their past and present.
content: On a summer lawn outside Ballybeg Hall, the O’Donnell siblings loll under lemony sunlight perfect for a family reunion. A wedding has lured back two of the émigrés among them, but Claire, the bride-to-be, has always lived at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: In Paris, Stars Going Shopping
description: What to wear on the red carpet? Schiaparelli, Dior and Chanel have some ideas. Armani, too.
content: The fact that the big Oscar nominations reveal fell right in the middle of the Paris couture shows was a coincidence, but a fortuitous one. After all, ever since the end of the actors’ strike, the red carpet has been a veritable explosion of pent-up fashion fantasy. What better place to shop for that than at the couture?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: For ‘Barbie’ Fans Online, a Bitterly Ironic Oscar Snub
description: Greta Gerwig and Margot Robbie missed Academy Award nominations for director and actress, respectively — a fact that was a little too on the nose for some.
content: When the 2024 Oscar nominations were announced this morning, the snubs of the two most prominent women involved in “Barbie” — the director, Greta Gerwig, and the lead actress, Margot Robbie — became the breakout story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: They Fly. They Spin. They Change How You See the Amazing.
description: In Compagnie Hervé Koubi’s “Sol Invictus” at the Joyce Theater, the dancers’ extraordinary moves are integrated into a poetic vision.
content: The dancers of Compagnie Hervé Koubi spend a lot of time upside down. Inverted, they spin on one or both hands or on their heads, legs spiraling. Upright, they bound into the air, as if off trampolines, ball up their bodies and rapidly rotate in high-flying arcs. They toss one another even higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Delta Air Lines Boeing 757 Lost Nose Wheel Before Takeoff, F.A.A. Says
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the latest troubling event involving a Boeing aircraft.
content: A Boeing 757 plane operated by Delta Air Lines lost a nose wheel as it prepared to take off from Atlanta’s main airport on Saturday, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. It was the latest troubling episode involving one of the manufacturer’s aircraft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden, Brushing Off Gaza Protesters at Rally, Calls for Restoring Abortion Rights
description: The event was interrupted by at least 10 people protesting the war in Gaza, but the president focused on calling attention to restrictive abortion laws.
content: President Biden headlined a rally in support of abortion rights on Tuesday, trying to focus on an issue that has galvanized his supporters even as he was interrupted every few minutes by at least 10 people protesting the war in Gaza, an issue that has just as quickly divided Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Playboi Carti, Waxahatchee and 12 More to Watch
description: A breakdown of new albums and songs for 2024 (and a handful of possible but dubious releases).
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: Behind the Plan to Build a City From Scratch in Solano County
description: The company California Forever began collecting signatures last week for a ballot initiative that would essentially ask residents for permission to build.
content: Residents of Rio Vista, an agricultural town of 10,000 near the edge of Solano County, have been captivated for most of the last six years by one question: Who was buying up all the farmland?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Barnard College’s Restrictions on Political Speech Prompt Outcry
description: Professors and free speech advocates are protesting a decision by the college to monitor and remove pro-Palestinian statements and other speech the college deems too political.
content: Three weeks after the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel, the Department of Women’s, Gender and Sexuality Studies at Barnard College in New York posted a statement on its departmental website in support of the Palestinian people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Minnesota State Trooper Charged with Murder in Shooting of Motorist
description: An investigation into the fatal shooting of Ricky Cobb II during a traffic stop last year exposed tensions between law enforcement officials and prosecutors.
content: Prosecutors charged a Minnesota state trooper with second-degree murder on Wednesday in the fatal shooting of a motorist who drove away during a traffic stop last summer in Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Why Making Face Computers Cool Isn’t Easy
description: Starting with Google Glass, all have been plagued with the same issues, even as Apple plunges into the market with its Vision Pro.
content: After years of anticipation, Apple’s first major new product in nearly a decade has arrived. The $3,500 Vision Pro, a face computer that resembles ski goggles, will be released next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What Happens After You Ask if Your Date Is Pro-Choice?
description: For the under-30 set, it really depends.
content: A few weeks ago, when I asked Times readers under 30 how politics influences their dating lives, I expected that the subject of reproductive choice would come up pretty frequently. After all, there are few political issues that affect dating and relationships quite as intimately or permanently, and since the overturning of Roe v. Wade in 2022, theirs is the first generation of young people since the 1970s who may be living in states where abortion isn’t legal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: We Are Normalizing Trump. Again.
description: Can the former president forge an enduring coalition out of his cult of personality?
content: Over the past nine years, Donald Trump has been variously described as narcissistic, mendacious, authoritarian, unbalanced, ignorant, incompetent, egotistic and racist — as someone who demonizes minorities and fans ethnic hostility. These assessments are a major reason roughly half of American voters, according to polls, say they will not vote for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Male Vanity as Political Weakness
description: On the campaign trail, Nikki Haley questioned Donald J. Trump’s vitality. Her jabs seemed to penetrate.
content: If vanity is the soft underbelly of maleness, a vulnerable area between the armor of masculinity and the kill zone, it appears it was Donald J. Trump’s famous self-regard that was the target when Nikki Haley ramped up her attacks on her opponent in New Hampshire this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: How Haley Lost New Hampshire: Ignoring Lessons From Underdogs of the Past
description: The state has offered defeated candidates second chances and improbable victories, but Nikki Haley couldn’t get voters to throw her a life vest.
content: Senator John McCain’s first town hall in May 1999 was awful. Thirteen people milled around at a nearly empty American Legion Hall in Manchester, and only nine of them were still deciding whom to vote for in the first-in-the-nation primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: MoMA Sued by Artist Who Performed Nude in Marina Abramovic Work
description: The artist, John Bonafede, says museum officials failed to prevent visitors from sexually assaulting performers in the 2010 show.
content: A performance artist has sued the Museum of Modern Art, saying that officials neglected to take corrective action after several visitors groped him during a nude performance for the 2010 retrospective “Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Processes the New Hampshire Primary
description: Kimmel said Republicans had a choice between “the woman who would become their party’s first-ever female nominee for president or the first guy on trial for defamation related to sexual assault.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump’s Win Adds to Air of Inevitability as Haley Sharpens Edge
description: The former president’s victories in Iowa last week and in New Hampshire on Tuesday leave his main Republican rival, Nikki Haley, with an uphill battle.
content: Donald J. Trump’s victory in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday provided him the second of an opening pair of wins in the Republican nomination fight that accelerated his push for the party to coalesce behind him and deepened questions about the path forward for Nikki Haley, his lone remaining rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Fear the Tails, Not the Jaws, of These ‘Weirdo’ Sharks
description: Scientists studied how thresher sharks use “extreme yoga” to whip their tails at prey.
content: When a thresher shark attacks, it doesn’t lunge in teeth-first. Instead, it approaches a school of fish, lowers its head, flexes its body and thwaps its whiplike tail over its head. The smack of the thresher’s tail stuns a few unlucky fish, which the shark then gobbles up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: What’s Next for Trump, and Hollywood’s China Problem
description: Plus, an untested execution method.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Powerful Waves Slam U.S. Army Base in the Marshall Islands
description: A video circulating on social media showed water rushing into a room at U.S. Army Garrison Kwajalein Atoll as a series of unexpected waves surged across the low-lying island of Roi-Namur.
content: A surge of unexpected waves swamped the island of Roi-Namur in the Marshall Islands on Saturday, forcing evacuations from a U.S. military base and causing damage that could take months to repair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Pets Are Vulnerable to Cold Weather, Too
description: Here’s how to keep them safe when temperatures plummet.
content: When biting cold hits, pet owners wonder how to keep their animals safe and comfortable. And veterinarians say that it is reasonable to be concerned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: What Is Your Reaction to the Presidential Race So Far?
description: Donald J. Trump made history with a second straight victory, while President Biden is cruising to renomination.
content: Please note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our Student Opinion questions and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on nytimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only forum that explicitly invites the voices of young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin, Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: The News About the News Business Is Getting Grimmer
description: Mass layoffs, closures and reader fatigue are afflicting news organizations as Americans prepare for a consequential election year.
content: Even by the standards of a news business whose fortunes have plummeted in the digital age, the last few weeks have been especially grim for American journalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: All Breakfast, All the Time
description: Spicy, cheesy eggs Kejriwal, broiled salmon with mustard and lemon and miso-pecan banana bread are delicious at any hour.
content: I’m a big breakfast person, but I don’t tend to eat it in the morning. To me, the magic of runny eggs with buttered toast or a piping hot bowl of creamy steel-cut oats is best enjoyed languorously at the end of the day, not in that semi-caffeinated fog typical of a weekday morning. I adore breakfast as long as it’s for dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Have You Lived Out of Your Storage Unit? We Would Like to Hear From You.
description: With the housing crisis worsening and homelessness on the rise, some people have resorted to living out of storage units. Please contact us if you have.
content: The housing crisis has become so extreme that there is now not a single state, metropolitan area, or county in the United States where a person earning the federal minimum wage can afford market rent on a modest two-bedroom apartment. Homelessness is growing. Tens of thousands of people have resorted to living out of their cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Mayor Wins Second Primary, After a Fall Race Marred by Ballot Abuse
description: A judge ordered Bridgeport, Conn., to rerun its Democratic primary for mayor after videos of ballot stuffing surfaced. But first, the city held a general election.
content: Joe Ganim, the longtime mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., won the city’s Democratic mayoral primary on Tuesday — months after winning the general election and an earlier primary.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Research Reveals Remnants of Sprawling Ancient Cities in the Amazon Rainforest
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 24, 2024.
content: “This idea of a kind of pristine, untouched Amazonian landscape was definitely not the case.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: That Famous Black Hole Gets a Second Look
description: Repeated studies of the supermassive black hole in the galaxy Messier 87 confirm that it continues to act as Einstein’s theory predicted it would.
content: Hello darkness, our old friend, we’ve come to stare at you again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: British Court Answers an Eternal Question: How Much Potato Does a Crisp Contain?
description: A snack company’s yearslong effort to protect the sanctity of its poppadom spuddered — er, sputtered — in a tax tribunal this month.
content: No profit grows, Shakespeare once wrote, where no pleasure is taken. And so in the tedious march of life, we find joy in small things: The rising of the sun. A fine glass of wine. The greasy snap of a well-dressed potato crisp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Nikki Haley Was an Illusion. It Just Shattered.
description: We were desperate to believe that someone could stop Donald Trump.
content: Nikki Haley was made for New Hampshire. New Hampshire was made for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Brad Stone Named Editor of Bloomberg Businessweek
description: Mr. Stone will take the helm as the 94-year-old magazine shifts from weekly to monthly publication.
content: Brad Stone, a veteran technology journalist, will be the next editor of Bloomberg Businessweek, the company said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Simple Ingredient Makes So Many Meals Shine
description: Coconut milk effortlessly lends its subtly sweet flavor and richness to countless recipes.
content: As much as I worship the seasonal and the fresh when it comes to ingredients, there are a handful of canned products that are sacred in my kitchen. Coconut milk is one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Yale, Duke and Columbia Among Elite Schools to Settle in Price-Fixing Case
description: Five universities have agreed to pay $104.5 million to settle a lawsuit accusing them of violating an agreement to be “need-blind” when admitting students.
content: For almost a quarter of a century, a coterie of the nation’s most elite universities had a legal shield: They would be exempt from federal antitrust laws when they shared formulas to measure prospective students’ financial needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: ‘Tired of Being Quiet,’ Sarah Jarosz Tests the Mainstream
description: With her new album, “Polaroid Lovers,” a luminary of Americana broadens her sound.
content: In modern Nashville, songwriting is often a matter of professionalized co-writing: planned, mix-and-match collaborations by appointment, musicians sharing a room to come up with sturdy material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar and Bernhard Warner
title: Boeing Faces Backlash From Airline Chiefs
description: The aircraft maker’s customers are going public with their frustrations, hoping their tough comments will force the company to improve quality control and engineering.
content: Airline bosses have lashed out at Boeing over a streak of safety and production problems — loose bolts, a discarded wrench found under the floorboards, delayed shipments — as scrutiny over the company’s manufacturing processes intensifies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Best Bowl of Beans I’ve Ever Had
description: A pantry staple can be exciting, even thrilling, with a little time, care and cleverness.
content: Hillary Sterling is home for dinner just three nights a week. The other nights, she works as the executive chef of Ci Siamo, a bustling restaurant in Manhattan, where her team serves the best bowl of braised beans I’ve ever had.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Trump-Haley Race After New Hampshire
description: Readers analyze the primary results and urge Nikki Haley to keep running. Also: The U.S. and Israel; freedom of speech; dumping and donating.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: Blue Whale Genes Reveal Less Inbreeding, More Interbreeding Than Expected
description: Researchers completed genomic research on carcasses of the largest animals that have ever lived to understand North Atlantic whale populations.
content: In 2014, nine blue whales died after being trapped by ice near Newfoundland, Canada. Two of their carcasses washed ashore and began bloating as they decomposed, causing worries of an imminent explosion and possibly inspiring a sketch on “Saturday Night Live” that ended with Charlize Theron covered in whale guts. More recently, the colossal corpses of these unlucky mammals have made an important contribution to science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: New Hampshire’s G.O.P. Primary Sets a State Turnout Record
description: With Donald Trump on the ballot, the voting surge underscored his ability to drive loyal supporters and determined opposition to the polls.
content: A record number of voters cast a ballot in New Hampshire’s Republican primary on Tuesday, according to a New York Times analysis of election data, as former President Donald J. Trump cruised to an easy victory over Nikki Haley, his last remaining rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘In the Know’ Review: This American Narcissist
description: Mike Judge’s latest comedy, an animated sendup of a public radio talk show, offers artisanal awfulness.
content: Mike Judge was a creator of the happily mordant HBO comedy “Silicon Valley” and Zach Woods was a key member of its ensemble cast. They must have enjoyed the time they spent working together, because they have teamed up again for “In the Know” (premiering Thursday on Peacock), another biting workplace satire set in a subculture ripe for mockery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero
title: Naomi Watts, Demi Moore and Diane Lane Swan at the Plaza
description: The stars of Ryan Murphy’s new series, “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans,” celebrated the premiere at the site of the famed 1966 Black and White Ball.
content: On Tuesday night, actresses, producers and television executives, many draped in black and white feathered gowns, trickled into the Plaza Hotel to celebrate the premiere of FX’s “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans,” a limited series starting on Jan. 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vik Jolly, Corina Knoll and Tim Arango
title: ‘Out of an Apocalyptic Movie’: San Diego Residents Describe Flood Escape
description: The San Diego region was overwhelmed by a surprisingly intense storm that flooded homes and turned roadways into rivers. Some residents wondered why they did not receive more warning.
content: They fled to rooftops. Deserted cars in the middle of raging waters. Grabbed kayaks to traverse flooded streets. Searched for neighbors and cried out to strangers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Honed at Home in Yemen, Houthi Propaganda Is Going Global
description: As the war in Gaza gives the Houthi militia an international audience, the group has seized the opportunity to take its message far beyond Yemen’s borders.
content: Soon after Yemen’s Houthi militia hijacked a commercial ship in the Red Sea, taking it and its 25-member crew hostage, the armed group used the vessel to record a music video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: After Early Primary Victories, Republicans in Congress Fall in Line Behind Trump
description: The former president’s win in New Hampshire has melted away much of the remaining opposition to him among Republicans on Capitol Hill.
content: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the Georgia Republican and die-hard ally of former President Donald J. Trump, was exasperated with her colleagues as she left the House floor last Thursday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden Wasn’t on the Ballot in New Hampshire. He Won Anyway.
description: The comfortable, though symbolic, victory comes as President Biden turns his focus to the general election.
content: President Biden’s decisive victory in the New Hampshire Democratic presidential primary provided him with a dose of good political news amid a season of Democratic anxiety about his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
title: Israel and Hamas’s Cease-Fire and Hostage Deal Proposals: What to Know
description: The negotiations continue, but the sides are far apart on issues including the fate of Hamas’s top leadership in the Gaza Strip.
content: Israel and Hamas continued indirect talks on a cease-fire on Wednesday, but the gap between the sides remained wide, especially on two issues: the length of any pause in fighting, and the fate of Hamas leaders in Gaza, according to officials briefed on the talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Matt Stevens
title: Jon Stewart Will Return to Host ‘The Daily Show’ on Mondays
description: Stewart, who hosted the Comedy Central show from 1999 to 2015, will also be an executive producer.
content: Jon Stewart is returning to late night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Webster Ayuso
title: A Boom in Comics Drawn From Fact
description: One in four books sold in France is a graphic novel. Increasingly, those include nonfiction works by journalists and historians.
content: Soon after the journalist and historian Valérie Igounet heard about the killing of Samuel Paty, the schoolteacher whose 2020 murder by an Islamist extremist shocked France, she knew she wanted to write a book about him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph P. Fried
title: Howard Golden, Who Led, and Defended, Brooklyn, Dies at 98
description: Before it staged a revival, he was the borough’s president and Democratic leader for a quarter-century, sometimes clashing with mayors.
content: Howard Golden, who as Brooklyn borough president for a quarter-century pressed to strengthen the borough economically and defended it against slights real or perceived in the years before it experienced a gentrifying revival, died on Wednesday at his home in the Kensington section of Brooklyn. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Climate Change Drove Drought in the Amazon
description: The world’s largest river and rainforest was parched by extreme temperatures last year that would have been highly unlikely without climate change, scientists said.
content: Climate change fueled the remarkable 2023 drought that drained major rivers, fueled huge wildfires and threatened the livelihoods of millions of people in the Amazon rainforest, scientists said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Ameera Harouda
title: Israeli Soldiers Clearing Buffer Zone in Gaza Die in Blast
description: On the deadliest day for Israelis since the ground invasion against Hamas began, about 20 soldiers were killed as they prepared to level buildings near the border.
content: The Israeli military suffered the deadliest day of its ground invasion of the Gaza Strip on Monday when 24 soldiers were killed, about 20 of them in an explosion as they were preparing to level buildings to help create a buffer zone with the Palestinian enclave, Israeli officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Netflix Is Said to License ‘Sex and the City’ From HBO
description: Media companies that had been reluctant to are increasingly offering shows to Netflix, which is pulling further ahead in the streaming wars.
content: HBO is renting out one of its most valuable series to Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $10 Million Homes in Virginia, Massachusetts and Illinois
description: An 1856 estate in Keswick, a six-bedroom compound on Nantucket and a Colonial Revival house in Hinsdale.
content: This house, listed on the National Register of Historic Places, has been updated by the sellers, who installed new appliances, a new electrical system and new plumbing during renovations, and also uncovered original floorboards and an original kitchen fireplace, which is now the centerpiece of a lower-level den.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
title: A Nationwide Shutdown Tests Milei’s Tough Medicine for Argentina
description: Argentine unions are striking to protest President Javier Milei’s economic policies, which have accelerated inflation. He says they are needed to fix the country.
content: It has been six weeks since President Javier Milei took office in Argentina, and since then, gas prices have doubled, inflation has soared and the value of the national currency has plummeted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: 6-Day Rail Strike Halts Most Trains in Germany
description: The walkout, over pay and hours, is the most significant in years at the national train operator, which warned of a “massive reduction” in service.
content: Passenger train drivers in Germany walked off the job on Wednesday and vowed not to return for six days in a strike over working conditions and pay that was expected to halt most long-distance and commuter rail travel across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacey Freed
title: Amid a Housing Crunch, Religious Groups Unlock Land to Build Homes
description: Faith-based organizations are unlocking their real estate to develop affordable housing, but they face challenges from reluctant local residents, wary lenders and strict zoning laws.
content: Emma Budway, a 26-year-old autistic woman who is mostly nonverbal, had been living with her parents in Arlington, Va. She longed for her own place, but because she earned little income, she could not afford to move out. So when the opportunity came to move into a two-bedroom apartment in December 2019, she jumped at the chance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Orban Uses Sweden’s NATO Bid to Take Center Stage in Europe
description: The Hungarian leader has repeatedly opposed European efforts to boost Europe’s security in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. He also blocked a $52 billion aid package for Ukraine.
content: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary pledged on Wednesday to push legislators to vote for Sweden’s admittance into NATO, as he faced mounting pressure as the last holdout blocking its entry to the military alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Murder on a Private Greek Island
description: The setting of “The Fury,” the new novel by Alex Michaelides, is stunning. Its plot? Not so much.
content: Alex Michaelides, who is best known for his blockbuster first novel, “The Silent Patient,” has a devoted following and a knack for explosive, change-everything revelations. He sets THE FURY (Celadon, 298 pp., $28.99) on a private Greek island where Lana Farrar, a stunningly beautiful British movie star, has gathered a small party of relatives and frenemies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jonathan Weisman, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Alex Stern, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachel Quester, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Why the G.O.P. Nomination Fight Is Now (All But) Over
description: Donald Trump won the Republican primary in New Hampshire over his lone rival, Nikki Haley.
content: On Tuesday, Donald J. Trump beat Nikki Haley in New Hampshire. His win accelerated a push for the party to coalesce behind him and deepened questions about the path forward for Ms. Haley, his lone remaining rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: After New Hampshire, Business Braces for a Trump Nomination
description: Donald Trump cruised to victory in the state’s Republican primary, leaving anti-Trump donors and others to grapple with the reality of a near-certain nomination.
content: As widely expected, Donald Trump handily won the New Hampshire Republican primary, defeating Nikki Haley by double digits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: White House Said to Delay Decision on Enormous Natural Gas Export Terminal
description: Before deciding whether to approve it, the Energy Department will analyze the climate impacts of CP2, one of 17 proposed LNG export terminals.
content: The Biden administration is pausing a decision on whether to approve what would be the largest natural gas export terminal in the United States, a delay that could stretch past the November election and spell trouble for that project and 16 other proposed terminals, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: San Francisco Tried to Build a $1.7 Million Toilet. It’s Still Not Done.
description: An expensive public bathroom project has come to symbolize the city’s bureaucratic inefficiencies.
content: You could say San Francisco’s charming Noe Valley neighborhood has it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Wesley Parnell
title: The New Migrant Shelter Hurdle: Waiting for the City to Call No. 14,861
description: New York City is required to give a bed to anyone who asks. But as the city reaches a new phase in its homelessness crisis, officials are telling people they have to wait.
content: Moises Chacon is number 14,861. Jon Cordero’s number is in the 15,000s. Oumar Camara’s wristband says he is number 16,700.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The What-Ifs of Trump’s New Hampshire Win
description: Trump’s win hints that we were only a few what-ifs away from a more competitive campaign.
content: Like his victory in Iowa last week, Donald Trump’s defeat of Nikki Haley in New Hampshire was substantial enough to remove any real doubt about the outcome of the primary campaign yet also somewhat underwhelming as a statement of voter enthusiasm for a former president and de facto incumbent candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Profit From Car Sales Falls as Price Cuts Hurt
description: A tax benefit boosted quarterly earnings, but that masked a decline in earnings from carmaking caused by intensifying competition.
content: Tesla’s profit from sales of electric cars slumped in the last three months of last year because of price cuts intended to thwart increasingly intense competition, the company said on Wednesday as it warned of a tough year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Lisa Lerer
title: New Hampshire and Iowa Reveal Broader Weaknesses for Trump
description: As Donald J. Trump pivots to a general election, early results point at the rough road ahead with critical independent voters.
content: For weeks, Donald J. Trump has romped through Iowa and New Hampshire without breaking a sweat, muscling out rivals for the Republican nomination and soaking up adoration from crowds convinced he will be the next president of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Shipping Costs Soar in Wake of Red Sea Attacks
description: Ships risking Houthi attacks must pay high insurance premiums, while vessels avoiding the region lose time going around Africa.
content: For about two months, a barrage of missile and drone attacks in the Red Sea by Houthi militants has posed a difficult choice to shippers using the Suez Canal: risk an airborne strike and pay sharply higher insurance rates, or forgo the canal and take the longer route around Africa, snarling schedules and entailing higher fuel charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Haley’s Fancy-but-Not-So-Fancy Dress May Have Been Just What She Intended
description: What Donald J. Trump meant as a barb at his rival, Nikki Haley, may have ultimately highlighted the look, and the message, she was going for.
content: It wasn’t only Nikki Haley’s promise after the New Hampshire Republican primary that she would continue to fight that got under Donald J. Trump’s skin, apparently; it was her clothes, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Biggest British-American Tea Kerfuffle Since … Well, You Know
description: An American chemistry professor has a surprising thought about how to make the best cup of tea: Add a pinch of salt. Not everyone in Britain is eager to embrace the idea.
content: Can a simple cup of tea stir a dispute between two mighty countries on opposite sides of the Atlantic? Just ask the ragtag group of patriots who crudely disguised themselves and hurled chests of tea into Boston Harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Military Plane Crashes in Russia, Killing All Aboard, Moscow Says
description: The Russian Defense Ministry claimed that the transport plane was carrying 65 Ukrainian prisoners of war and accused Ukraine of shooting it down. The claims could not be independently verified.
content: A large Russian military transport plane crashed on Wednesday near the border with Ukraine, killing everyone onboard, the Russian Defense Ministry said, accusing Ukraine of shooting down the plane with missiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The U.S. strikes 2 more Houthi targets in Yemen.
description: The attacks — the ninth in two weeks — hit anti-ship missiles that the Iran-backed militia could use against merchant and Navy ships in the region.
content: The United States struck two Houthi anti-ship missiles in Yemen, the military’s Central Command said on Tuesday, resuming what U.S. officials said were short-notice attacks against the Iran-backed militia’s imminent threats to merchant vessels, as well as Navy ships in the Red Sea and nearby waters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Antolini, Lynn Levy, Diane Wong and Sopan Deb
title: What’s Up With Cookie Monster’s Cookies?
description: Our reporter uncovers the secrets behind the Sesame Street character’s favorite treat.
content: Years ago, New York Times Reporter Sopan Deb got an email that asked: “What’s the deal with the cookies that Cookie Monster eats?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Rabkin Peachman
title: Is Dyeing Your Hair Bad for Your Health?
description: Here’s what the research suggests about the link between hair dye and cancer.
content: Q. I color my hair regularly, but I’ve heard that permanent hair dye can increase the risk of cancer. Should I be worried?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Hiba Yazbek
title: Israel Orders Evacuation of Packed Gaza Area With 2 Major Hospitals
description: Hundreds of thousands of people, most of them already displaced by the war, are in the evacuation zone, part of the city of Khan Younis, the United Nations said.
content: Thousands of people were trapped at a hospital by heavy fighting in southern Gaza, and Israeli forces on Wednesday had surrounded a second hospital where displaced people were sheltering, aid agencies said, after Israel’s military ordered evacuations for that part of the city of Khan Younis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Fire Rips Through Abkhazia Gallery, Destroying Nearly 4,000 Artworks
description: This Georgian region lost a collection that is considered a national treasure, but only Russia and a few allies recognize it as a nation at all.
content: A fire in Abkhazia, a Russian-backed breakaway region of Georgia, destroyed thousands of paintings early Sunday morning, devastating a collection that locals had cherished as a national treasure — albeit of a country only recognized as such by Russia and some of its allies, including Syria and Venezuela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: An Olympic Dream Falters Amid Track’s Shifting Rules
description: Track and field’s decision to bar intersex athletes from women’s events has raised questions about fair play and inclusion ahead of the Paris Games.
content: Maximila Imali, a top Kenyan sprinter, did not lose her eligibility to compete in the Paris Olympics because she cheated. She did not fail a doping test. She broke no rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Kennedy
title: Carl Andre, Austerely Minimalist Sculptor, Is Dead at 88
description: He worked with elemental metals, granite, wood and brick in sculpture “free of human association.” His career was marred by accusations that he had a role in his wife’s fatal plunge.
content: Carl Andre, one of the most influential and ascetic pioneers of Minimalist sculpture, whose career was overshadowed by the accusation that he played a role in the death of his wife, the Cuban American artist Ana Mendieta, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: #MeToo and the Next Mayoral Election
description: Three potential candidates for mayor in 2025 have been accused of sexual misconduct. Will that matter to voters?
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at #MeToo and candidates in New York. We’ll also look at what Senator Robert Menendez says the F.B.I. did to his house in a search in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Naomi Feil, Who Promoted Empathy as a Response to Dementia, Dies at 91
description: She trained caregivers to “validate” the delusions of older people with dementia, rather than try to wrest them into the real world.
content: Naomi Feil was only 8 years old when she moved into what was then known as a home for the aged, where her parents worked. Living there until she left for college, she learned firsthand, by trial and error, how to comfort and communicate with older adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: When Masters of Black-and-White Spin the Color Wheel
description: A centenary exhibition of Saul Leiter’s photos reveals his painterly way with Kodachrome. And a new book shows that Garry Winogrand worked best in two tones.
content: When Saul Leiter began shooting Kodachrome slides in New York in the late 1940s, color was scorned by most serious photographers, who thought of it as a hobby for vacationing dads or the commercial domain of magazines and advertising agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: On a Budget, a Travel Reporter Learns Invaluable Lessons
description: Lengthy layovers, lost bags and last-minute panic: Elaine Glusac has experienced it all (and then some) as the Frugal Traveler columnist.
content: “Do you need someone to carry your bags?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: The Israeli military suffered its deadliest day of the Gaza ground invasion on Monday, announcing that 24 soldiers had been killed, about 20 of them in an explosion inside the territory near the Israeli border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Littlest Speck
description: John-Clark Levin expands his repertoire.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Am I That Guy? A View From the Front Rows in Paris
description: Projecting himself into the latest styles in Paris, our critic poses the perennial question: “Could I pull that off?”
content: Am I that guy? The question is both nagging and inescapable if you follow the men’s wear circuit, as I recently did — attending roughly 50 shows or presentations displayed in settings as disparate as school auditoriums, gilded ballrooms and construction sites where niceties like fire safety are notional at best.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clark D. Cunningham
title: Why Fani Willis Should Step Aside in the Trump Case in Georgia
description: The case is more important than any individual actor managing the prosecution.
content: ATLANTA — The case against Donald Trump in Georgia for allegedly participating in a criminal conspiracy to interfere with the 2020 election is more important than any individual actor managing the prosecution, and that includes the Fulton County district attorney, Fani Willis, and the case’s lead prosecutor, Nathan Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anshel Pfeffer
title: The Man Who Could Unseat Netanyahu
description: In the wake of the Oct. 7 attacks, Benny Gantz has emerged as the most likely candidate to take on Israel’s current prime minister.
content: Just over 100 days ago, Benny Gantz was the leader of a small Israeli opposition party. Now, in a shared office inside a nondescript building within the Defense Ministry compound in Tel Aviv, Mr. Gantz is helping lead Israel’s war against Hamas in Gaza as a member of the war cabinet formed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: How a Ragtag Militia in Yemen Became a Nimble U.S. Foe
description: The Iran-backed Houthis perfected the tactics of irregular warfare during years of conflict against a Saudi-led coalition, military officials say.
content: For years, the scrappy Iran-backed Yemeni rebels known as the Houthis did such a good job of bedeviling American partners in the Middle East that Pentagon war planners started copying some of their tactics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Is ‘Back From the Brink,’ Mayor Says in Upbeat Speech
description: In his third State of the City speech, Mayor Eric Adams played down the migrant crisis and focused on a dip in crime and rise in jobs in the city.
content: After facing mounting challenges in his second year in office, Mayor Eric Adams on Wednesday used his third State of the City address to deliver a rah-rah overview of his tenure, highlighting improvements in public safety and jobs while playing down the migrant crisis that has overwhelmed New York City’s shelter system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Can the World’s Largest Cruise Ship Really Be Climate-Friendly?
description: The newly christened Icon of the Seas is filled with energy-efficient technology. But some climate experts say the biggest challenge with a ship that can accommodate nearly 8,000 people is its size.
content: On Tuesday, in a ceremony that, of course, involved a soccer ball, the Argentine soccer superstar Lionel Messi pressed a button and a bottle of champagne smashed against the bow of Icon of the Seas, christening the world’s largest cruise ship at its home port of Miami. Like an A-list celebrity stepping onto the red carpet, the arrival of Royal Caribbean’s 250,800-ton ship has captured the world’s attention, with some marveling over its cutting-edge features, like the largest water park at sea, while others criticize the gigantic ship’s potential to damage the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: An Important Victory
description: New Hampshire was Nikki Haley’s best opportunity to change the trajectory of the race. She didn’t.
content: Is the Republican presidential primary over already?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers, Noam Scheiber and Jonathan Weisman
title: Biden Receives Endorsement from United Automobile Workers Union
description: The group, which endorsed President Biden in the 2020 election, made the self-described most “pro-union president in history” work for its official approval.
content: The United Automobile Workers union endorsed President Biden on Wednesday, delivering an influential boost as he faces a battle against former President Donald J. Trump to win the support of labor groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: 5 Takeaways From the New Hampshire Primary
description: Donald Trump made history with a second straight victory, as Nikki Haley and her supporters look increasingly adrift in his Republican Party.
content: The much-fabled power of New Hampshire’s fiercely independent voters wasn’t enough to break the spell Donald J. Trump has cast over the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: Military Plane Crashes in Russia
description: Plus, can the world’s biggest cruise ship be climate friendly?
content: A large Russian military transport plane crashed yesterday in the Belgorod region near the border with Ukraine, killing everyone onboard, the Russian Defense Ministry said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: How Could My Brother-in-Law’s Twin Abandon Him During Cancer Treatment?
description: After offering his brother lodging for his course of radiation therapy, the man informed him — with one day’s notice — that the invitation was contingent on an apology for a long-forgotten letter.
content: My sister’s husband was diagnosed with prostate cancer last year. Along with his oncologist, he consulted frequently with his twin brother, who is a doctor. They decided he should have surgery, and then an eight-week course of specialized radiation that is available only at a handful of hospitals. His twin lives near one of them, and he invited my brother-in-law to stay with him and his wife in their large home for eight weeks. The day before my brother-in-law was set to drive there, his twin called and said he could stay with them only if he apologized to his wife for a letter he wrote 30 years earlier, shortly after his son died. (My brother-in-law doesn’t remember this letter or anyone referring to it before.) His twin said: “I have to choose between you and my marriage.” My brother-in-law says he understands, but my sister is heartbroken for him. Doesn’t the twin have to keep his word and let his brother stay at his house?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: It’s Fair to Ask: Is the Republican Race Over?
description: New Hampshire was just about the ideal state for Nikki Haley. It doesn’t get better from here.
content: Is the Republican presidential primary over already?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantel Tattoli
title: Can a Forgotten Hot Spot Reclaim Its Cool?
description: That’s the hope at the restaurant Maxim’s in Paris, which recently started a new chapter after 130 years in business.
content: Anya Firestone’s job as a luxury tour guide in Paris has brought her to many rarefied corners of the city. But only recently did she do something that countless locals and visitors have done over the last 130 years: Book a reservation at Maxim’s, the storied French restaurant that opened in 1893 and has counted Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Margrethe II of Denmark, Jean Cocteau, Jane Birkin and Man Ray among its patrons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: New Hampshire Showed Trump’s Strengths and Weaknesses
description: Also, a Russian military plane crashed near Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Donald Trump’s comfortable victory last night in New Hampshire’s Republican presidential primary demonstrated his ironclad control of the party’s right-wing base and set him on what could very well be a short march to his third nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Barbie’ Is Adapted? ‘Maestro’ Original? Let’s Fix the Screenplay Categories.
description: There’s a way to classify screenplays for Oscar consideration that would reward creativity and make much more sense. Unlike the current system.
content: In the midst of the squabbles about actors and directors, there’s always at least one screenplay to debate when Oscar nominations are announced. Last year, in fact, there were two, and I regularly get collared by people wondering: What in the world were “Glass Onion” and “Top Gun: Maverick” doing in the best adapted screenplay bucket? Adapted from what? Was there some secret book about fighter pilots or tech mogul whodunits they’d missed?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: At White Columns Annual, Outsiders Mix With Insiders
description: “Looking Back,” the nonprofit gallery’s group show, brings together self-taught and highly trained artists. It isn’t obvious who’s who.
content: It’s pleasantly disorienting to enter the White Columns Annual in New York in 2024 and see so much work that could have been, and was, made any time in the last half century. There’s not a screen, QR code or 3-D print in sight. But since its inauguration in 2006, the nonprofit gallery’s “Looking Back” series has made an old-school proposition: to curate a group show around one person’s (or collective’s) taste, shorn of commercial or institutional impulses to either move product or capture a zeitgeist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Unauthorized Renovation Work Caused Fire That Killed 39 in China
description: Nine people were also injured in the blaze, which officials said was a result of workers renovating a cold storage unit in violation of regulations.
content: A fire at a building in southeastern China that killed at least 39 people was set off by unauthorized renovation work, officials said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Chris Cameron
title: Haley Declares Race ‘Far From Over’ After Losing to Trump in New Hampshire
description: Defying calls from Donald Trump and his allies for her to drop out, Ms. Haley said in a fiery speech that she would forge ahead to South Carolina.
content: Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, on Tuesday defied calls to drop out of the race for the Republican nomination, vowing to fight on after a second straight defeat at the hands of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Patrick Healy, Jillian Weinberger and Vishakha Darbha
title: How Can Biden Woo Moderates?
description: After New Hampshire, the Never-Trump voters could be looking for a new home.
content: Opinion writer Michelle Cottle watched last night’s New Hampshire Primary results come in alongside supporters of Nikki Haley. She says the battle of head versus heart has just started. In this audio interview, Cottle speaks with Opinion’s deputy editor, Patrick Healy, to break down the primary polls, voter “vibes” and the feeling of déjà vu from 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: This ‘Expats’ Star Can’t Believe She’s Actually in It
description: Watching scenes of herself with Nicole Kidman, Ji-young Yoo said that “it still feels like I was Photoshopped in.” The Amazon series is one of three big coming projects for the 24-year-old.
content: In “Expats,” the actress Ji-young Yoo, a relative newcomer to Hollywood, shares the screen with Nicole Kidman, the Oscar- and Emmy-winning actress and producer. Yoo plays Mercy, a Columbia grad and would-be babysitter for the young son of Kidman’s Margaret, a former landscape architect and a mother of three living, none too happily, in Hong Kong. When Mercy loses her charge in a moment of distraction (yes, she was texting), it sends Margaret into — well, just imagine how Nicole Kidman might react if, say, you were texting and you lost her child.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Daily’: Stories on the Conflict Between Israel and Gaza
description: Listeners of “The Daily” hear Israelis and Gazans express their fears, hopes and experiences in real time.
content: When Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, “The Daily” began conceiving a series of personal stories. These five episodes are based on reporting, interviews and ideas original to “The Daily,” and reflect the goal of telling the story of the war with complexity and nuance through the voices of those living it in real time. Together, they form a mosaic that captures human stakes and heartbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Utility Must Pay $85 Million to People Affected by Oregon Wildfires, Jury Rules
description: The verdict is the latest legal development against PacifiCorp, which was found liable for damages for not cutting power to its customers during the devastating wildfires.
content: A jury in Portland, Ore., awarded $85 million on Tuesday to nine people who had losses from wildfires that devastated communities and burned millions of acres in September 2020. The verdict is the latest development against the electric utility company PacifiCorp over its responsibility for the fires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Meaning of Gaza’s Tunnels
description: Hamas could have devoted its money and time to building a future for its people, not a fortress for itself.
content: Ever since Israel withdrew its soldiers and settlers from Gaza in 2005, critics have accused it of blockading and immiserating the territory — turning it, as they say, into an “open-air prison.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Distracted Walking
description: Do you look at your phone while you walk? Is that a problem?
content: Are you glued to your device as you walk through the world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Crosley Coker
title: Female Rappers in the Spotlight Make Room for Motherhood
description: As their influence and success continue to grow, artists including Sexyy Red and Cardi B are destigmatizing motherhood for hip-hop performers.
content: When the rapper Sexyy Red realized she was pregnant with her second child this summer, just after her singles “Pound Town” and “SkeeYee” broke through on the charts and dominated TikTok, her excitement was met with hesitancy by some members of her team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: ‘Barbie’ Is Bad. There, I Said It.
description: There’s a crucial difference between liking the idea of a movie and liking the movie itself.
content: We can all agree 2023 was a good year for the movies. Critically and commercially, several movies did well, and only one of those successes took place within the Marvel cinematic universe. Even the 10 Oscar nominees for best picture, announced on Tuesday, included nine actually good films.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anastasia Tsioulcas
title: Review: The Philadelphia Orchestra Revels, and Struggles, in Jazz
description: At Carnegie Hall, a program of Stravinsky, Weill and freely improvised Gershwin highlighted a dialogue between jazz and classical music.
content: Much of 20th-century classical music owes a deep thanks to jazz. And while on paper, the Philadelphia Orchestra’s concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night was organized for a festival at the hall, Fall of the Weimar Republic: Dancing on the Precipice, the subtext was American jazz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A.I. Should Be a Tool, Not a Curse, for the Future of Work
description: Maybe machines will be able to take our jobs. But it doesn’t have to be that way.
content: If you aren’t already scared about artificial intelligence, you will be after you read the next sentence: “If science continues undisrupted, the chance of unaided machines outperforming humans in every possible task was estimated at 10 percent by 2027, and 50 percent by 2047.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: N.J. Transit Proposes Raising Fares 15% on July 1
description: The increase, which would be the first since 2015, would raise some commuters’ costs by more than $3 each way.
content: New Jersey’s financially troubled transit agency has decided who should pay to close its looming budget deficit: bus and train riders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Dan Wagoner, Acclaimed Modern Dancer, Is Dead at 91
description: He worked with the Martha Graham and Paul Taylor troupes and then created his own group, Dan Wagoner and Dancers.
content: Dan Wagoner, who danced with Martha Graham, was an early member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company and led his own well-regarded troupe for 25 years, died on Friday in Oakland, Md. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: What’s Next for Nikki Haley?
description: Stake it all on South Carolina? Hang in for the long haul? Reassess and drop out? Trump’s lone remaining challenger has some big decisions ahead. We look at her options.
content: Losing is never easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Europe Faces a Measles Outbreak
description: When vaccinations begin to lag, as they did during the pandemic, measles is often the first disease to resurge. “It’s the canary in the coal mine,” one expert said.
content: Measles, a disease preventable by vaccination, is resurgent in parts of Europe, including Britain. Small outbreaks have also popped up in multiple parts of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Princenthal
title: Cindy Sherman: Woman of an Uncertain Age
description: “I’m not going to go into this aging process silently or happily,” said the artist, who is emerging from a creative slump with electrifying new work.
content: The facial features in Cindy Sherman’s hyperenergetic new photo-portraits slide around crazily. Eyes spin out in different directions, competing clamorously for attention. Noses and mouths engage in pitched conflict. The electrifying images, now on view at Hauser and Wirth’s SoHo gallery, are primarily black and white, but there are patches of vivid color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Amy Harmon
title: Ohio to Ban Transition Care After Lawmakers Override Governor’s Veto
description: The law bans gender-affirming care for minors and prohibits transgender girls and women from playing on high school or college sports teams that match with their gender identity.
content: Ohio lawmakers on Wednesday overrode Gov. Mike DeWine’s veto of a bill that would bar transgender minors from receiving puberty blockers, hormone therapy or gender transition surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: What’s in Our Queue? Drake and More
description: I’m a New York Times reporter on the Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve been watching, listening to and playing.
content: I’m a New York Times reporter on the Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve been watching, listening to and playing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Glanz, Mika Gröndahl, Helmuth Rosales, Anjali Singhvi and Mark Walker
title: How Did a Boeing Jet End Up With a Big Hole?
description: The “door plug” that blew off an Alaska Airlines plane this month most likely had manufacturing or installation flaws.
content: The “door plug” that blew off an Alaska Airlines plane this month most likely had manufacturing or installation flaws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: How to Exercise When It Feels Impossible
description: We all have reasons we can’t work out as much as we should. You can get over them — just don’t call them excuses.
content: We all have reasons we can’t work out as much as we should. You can get over them — just don’t call them excuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Russian Military Plane Crashes Near Border With Ukraine
description: A video verified by The New York Times showed a large plane crashing and exploding in Yablonovo, a town in the Belgorod region of Russia.
content: A video verified by The New York Times showed a large plane crashing and exploding in Yablonovo, a town in the Belgorod region of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Trump Blasts Haley After Winning New Hampshire Primary
description: Donald J. Trump said that his rival Nikki Haley had a “very bad night“ and that his wins in New Hampshire and Iowa set him up to secure the G.O.P. nomination.
content: Donald J. Trump said that his rival Nikki Haley had a “very bad night“ and that his wins in New Hampshire and Iowa set him up to secure the G.O.P. nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By @WORLDMAVERICK Via Storyful
title: Giant Waves Surge Into U.S. Military Base in the Marshall Islands
description: An unexpected surge of waves crashed through a set of doors at U.S. Army Garrison Kwajalein Atoll on Roi-Namur, causing significant damage.
content: An unexpected surge of waves crashed through a set of doors at U.S. Army Garrison Kwajalein Atoll on Roi-Namur, causing significant damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Claire Hogan, Gabriel Blanco and Noah Throop
title: What Happened at the New Hampshire Primary
description: Former President Donald Trump won the New Hampshire primary, but Nikki Haley said the race is far from over.
content: Former President Donald Trump won the New Hampshire primary, but Nikki Haley said the race is far from over.
source.name: The New York Times
